bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to William Robertson, September 2, 1727

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to William Robertson, clerk of the Council, September 2, 1727, to thank him for an overabundance of military commissions and commenting on the news of the death of King George I, his pardoning of pirate John Vidal and the influence of Rev. Peter Fontaine on his decision, the militia expedition against the Indians, and Robertson's and his own health.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to William Robertson, September 2, 1727

opener.dateline:
Corotoman[, Lancaster County, Virginia]
Sepr. 2d. 1727
Mr. Wm. Robertson

div1.p:
You have now Supplyd me with Military
Commissions in abundance twice illegible Several more [illegible] than I writt for
however the proverb is a Store is no Sore,

The news of the Kings Death is Attended with
so many Circumstances there Seems hardly room left to disbelieve
it and yet that the King Should dye at Hanover the latter End of June
and that the news Should be in new York above a fortnight ago its
pretty Difficult to be Accounted for,

The Solicitation of Mr. Fountain and the Intercession
of so many worthy Gentlemen hath prevaild with me to reprieve
Vidall altho I must own to you I have very little Compassion
for persons Convicted of his Crime and let what mincing soever
be made use of in his favour It appeard very plainly to me
from the Testimony against him as well as the rest that his heart was
fully prepared for perpetrating the blackest of Crimes Vilianys Altho the
designe was laid with the greatest Improbability of Success, but tht.
was no foundation of merit in the Contrivors however Charity Should
Cover a multitude of Sins And may wee all meet with mercy in the
day of our distress Pray give my Service to Mr. Fountain whose
Concern in this affair hath had a great Influence upon me

I hope Colonel Harrison will be so Successfull in his En
terprize that our Frontier people in those parts will remain quiet
and unmolested in the Enjoyment of their little alls that some but
the Bruits will Envy them

When I hear of your health so soon when but a few
days before I had an Accot. of your life being in a great deal of dan
ger I cannot forbear having Some remains of hope of ourthat the report of the Kings decease be
ing yet alive Altho accompanyd with such Strong Circumstances
may yet prove a mistake My Gout hath proved more favorable
to me then my wishes I am Still lame my foot and Ankle Swelld
and Cant wear a Shooe I heartily wish you your firm health & am

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter letter book, 1727 May-1728 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.
The county, and colony have been added for clarity to this draft.
[1] George I (1660-1727) who reigned 1714-1727. ("The Royal English Monarchy." http://www.scotlandroyalty.org/kings.html. 11/12/03)

[2] Peter Fontaine (1691-1757) had been educated at Trinity Coillege, Dublin and was minister of James City Parish 1716-1720, and then of Westover Parish in Charles City County until his death. William Byrd was a parishoner and friend of Fontaine's who was chaplain of the boundary commission party in 1728-1729. (John K. Nelson. A Blessed Company: Parishes, Parsons, and Parishoners in Anglican Virginia, 1690-1776. [Chapel Hill and London: University of North Carolina Press, 2001]. pp. 98-99, 200, 310, 377, 396. )

[3] John Vidal was one of the three pirates captured in North Carolina who had been convicted and sentenced to death in a Vice Admiralty Court in Williamsburg in August See Carter's letters, 1727 July 24, to Sir Richard Everard, governor of North Carolina, and William Robertson, clerk of the Virginia Council. (McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 4[1721-1739]:144,149-50. )
[4] Carter refers to an expedition of the militia against the Indians that was being led by Nathaniel Harrison. See his letter to Harrison, 1727 August 7.
